citations.narrative:
The area inside of the sheltered portion of the ring-tailed lemur's housing facility, but outside of the primary enclosure had
a large amount of clutter, wires, tools and equipment piled and strewn on the floor. A large metal crank wrench on the
floor was within reach of the primary enclosure fencing, through which a lemur could stick a limb. Tools and equipment
within reach of animals inside their primary enclosures may pose an injury risk to the animal. Housing facilities must be
kept neat and free of any accumulation of trash, waste material, junk and other discarded materials.
Correct by 11 August 2023.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The singly housed adult female ring-tailed lemur "Buffy" that cannot see or hear other non-human primates does not have
a written plan for additional enrichment nor was receiving additional enrichment as required for this special consideration
animal. Individually housed nonhuman primates that are unable to see and hear nonhuman primates of their own or
compatible species may develop self-injurious behavior or poor psychological well-being. Certain nonhuman primates
must be provided special attention regarding enhancement of their environment, based on the needs of the individual
species and in accordance with instructions of the attending veterinarian.
Correct by 21 August 2023.

Multiple species of animals had water receptacles with thick green algae build-up completely covering the bottom of the
receptacles, organic debris floating on top of the water, and a few with high water turbidity that did not allow the bottom of
the receptacle to be viewed. Affected species were 1 adult coyote, 6 adult wallabies, 4 adult sheep, 1 adult alpaca, 4 adult
zebu, 4 ringtails and 1 adult raccoon. After the licensee cleaned and refilled the water container for the coyote, a majority
of algae was still present on the bottom. Improper cleaning of water containers and a lack of potable water does not
provide adequate relief from current high summer heat and weather conditions and may cause illness or injury to animals.
All water receptacles shall be kept clean and sanitary.
Correct from this date forward of 1 August 2023.

Both the attending veterinarian and the licensee confirmed the death of 2 adult wallabies (one male 10-year old and one
female 12-year old) in November-December 2022 that were housed together. The cause of death was considered to be
from fighting between the two animals. Incompatible animals housed together may cause injury or death to one another,
even when displaying natural behaviors such as those seen during breeding season. Animals housed in the same primary
enclosure must be compatible and shall not be housed near animals that interfere with their health.
Correct from this date forward of 1 August 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
n

narrative:
3.75(b) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
The area inside of the sheltered portion of the ring-tailed lemur's housing facility, but outside of the primary enclosure had 
a large amount of clutter, wires, tools and equipment piled and strewn on the floor. A large metal crank wrench on the 
floor was within reach of the primary enclosure fencing, through which a lemur could stick a limb. Tools and equipment 
within reach of animals inside their primary enclosures may pose an injury risk to the animal. Housing facilities must be 
kept neat and free of any accumulation of trash, waste material, junk and other discarded materials.  
 
Correct by 11 August 2023. 
3.81(c)(4) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The singly housed adult female ring-tailed lemur "Buffy" that cannot see or hear other non-human primates does not have 
a written plan for additional enrichment nor was receiving additional enrichment as required for this special consideration 
animal. Individually housed nonhuman primates that are unable to see and hear nonhuman primates of their own or 
compatible species may develop self-injurious behavior or poor psychological well-being. Certain nonhuman primates 
must be provided special attention regarding enhancement of their environment, based on the needs of the individual 
species and in accordance with instructions of the attending veterinarian.  
 
Correct by 21 August 2023. 
3.130  Direct
   
Watering. 
Multiple species of animals had water receptacles with thick green algae build-up completely covering the bottom of the 
receptacles, organic debris floating on top of the water, and a few with high water turbidity that did not allow the bottom of 
the receptacle to be viewed. Affected species were 1 adult coyote, 6 adult wallabies, 4 adult sheep, 1 adult alpaca, 4 adult 
zebu, 4 ringtails and 1 adult raccoon. After the licensee cleaned and refilled the water container for the coyote, a majority 
of algae was still present on the bottom. Improper cleaning of water containers and a lack of potable water does not 
provide adequate relief from current high summer heat and weather conditions and may cause illness or injury to animals.

All water receptacles shall be kept clean and sanitary. 
 
Correct from this date forward of 1 August 2023. 
3.133  Critical
   
Separation. 
Both the attending veterinarian and the licensee confirmed the death of 2 adult wallabies (one male 10-year old and one 
female 12-year old) in November-December 2022 that were housed together. The cause of death was considered to be 
from fighting between the two animals. Incompatible animals housed together may cause injury or death to one another, 
even when displaying natural behaviors such as those seen during breeding season. Animals housed in the same primary 
enclosure must be compatible and shall not be housed near animals that interfere with their health. 
 
Correct from this date forward of 1 August 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
